awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Commercializing a Passive Orthopedic Implant that Distributes Movement Between Tendons
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation--Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is three-fold.  First, in terms of societal impact, the project will develop biomedical implants that enables better surgical outcomes and quality of life for patients that undergo reconstructive orthopedic surgeries.  Importantly, these implants are passive---that is, they do not use external power, signals, motors, or electronics.  The proposed technology is different from existing solutions such as prostheses, orthoses, and exoskeletons as the implants enable the patient to make better use of their own muscle after a debilitating trauma.  Second, the project may pave the way for a new market for orthopedic implants that, when mounted on tendons, enable re-engineering the force and movement transmission within the body.  Third, this team will educate and train the next generation of engineering students to become leaders in commercializing novel biomedical implants and will conduct activities to increase the participation of women, under-represented minorities, and persons with disabilities.

The proposed project will advance the development of an implantable passive device for use in reconstructive orthopedic surgery.  Specifically, there are many hand surgeries where multiple tendons are rigidly sutured to one muscle.  Such surgeries only partially restore hand function.  This project will develop an implant which, when surgically inserted between biological flexor tendons, will significantly improve hand grasping capability for patients even if all four fingers are driven by only one muscle.  The project’s intellectual merit is two-fold.  First, the work will develop the science for the design, fabrication, and validation of pores that encourage long-term attachment between the implant and the tendon.  Second, the team will also design, fabricate, and validate a non-fouling coating that reduces scar tissue formation and increases the implant’s slickness.  The project considers the needs to reduce scarring on the implant's exterior surface while enabling tendon cells to migrate into the implant's pores for long-term attachment.  It is expected that the project may produce design and fabrication techniques to enhance tendon-implant attachment and reduce adverse biological response to implanted materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This NSF grant supported the research, development, and validation of a novel passive implant, the FlexRite®, for use in tendon-transfer surgery for conditions such as spinal cord injury.  

By doing so, the grant has laid a strong foundation for commercializing FlexRite®.  Tendon-transfer surgery using FlexRite® will significantly improve the distribution of movement from one muscle to multiple tendons when compared with the standard of care, which sutures the tendons together directly.  This grant has yielded the following outcomes, categorized as intellectual merit and broader impacts.

 

Intellectual merit

1. Significant improvements were made to the design of FlexRite® with iterative input from all partners (clinicians from Stanford University and Oregon Health Sciences University, Good Samaritan Regional Medical Center, researchers from the University of Washington and Columbia University, and surface-finishing manufacturing partner REM).  The improvements include design changes that enable 3D printing, eliminate the need for sutures, and promote natural in-growth, and developing a coating that significantly reduces fibrosis (see next bullet).

2. In conjunction with the University of Washington, developed a non-fouling coating for Titanium implants. Validation in this phase is five-fold: surface atomic composition, coating thickness, surface wettability, surface friction studies at UW, and strength testing at OSU.  Publication under preparation.

3. In conjunction with Columbia University, validated pore designs using an in vitro experiment to study implant-tendon integration. Data showed that a circular pore of 600 micron diameter supported best cell viability, when compared with 900 micron pores or square pores.  See Publication: H. Childs, H. Bestel, J. Casebier, E. Pacheco, R. Balasubramanian, and H. Lu, “Porous Titanium Implant for Soft-tissue In-growth and Biological fixation,” in Proceedings of the Society for Biomaterials, 2022.

4. Validated the implant using a three-week live-animal experiment in eight animals.  Data showed the following (publication under preparation):

4.1.  The coating reduced fibrosis by 57%.

4.2.  The implant enabled 37% better force distribution between the digits than was enabled by the contralateral tendon network

4.3.  The fibrotic capsule and pseudo-bursa did not resist movement.

5. Used PFI-TT APEX funding to file for three patents for technology developed during the project.

5.1.  Device for picking up and securing flexible material at low-tension levels

5.2.  Device for validating the abrasion resistance of a non-fouling coating

5.3.  Device for validating the security of holding an implant to a tendon

6. Documented that the coating and sterilization process does not weaken both RPU and Titanium (publication focusing on the RPU application under review)\

7. Submitted SBIR proposal to commercialize technology

8. Designed, fabricated, and validated a placement-guide instrument for holding and manipulating the FlexRite during surgery.  The team received funding from the Murdock Foundation and the OSU University Development Fund to develop it further.

9. Fielded a survey for collecting surgeon insight into the tendon-transfer surgery domain and OrthoMechanica’s technology.

10. Graduated one Robotics PhD student (Hantao Ling), one Bioengineering student (Prabhleen Kaur), and one Mechanical Engineering MS student (Justin Casebier)

11. Trained eight undergraduate students to conduct research in the domain of implantable mechanisms for orthopedic surgery.

 

Broader impacts

1. Trained students in understanding the interplay of interdisciplinary biomedical technology development, intellectual property protection, FDA regulation, and entrepreneurship.  One MS student who worked on this project graduated and joined the medical device industry as an engineer. Another PhD student joined a university medical center as a clinical trial analyst.

2. Trained students in developing partnerships with industry leaders and working alongside them through the NSF INTERN program.  As a result, students from the PI’s laboratory regularly interact with external partners (fabrication units) to define/specify the outsourced work and review and use the outsourced material.

3. Participated in two business development competitions

3.1.  Finalist at OSU’s University Summer Investment Opportunity.  Presented pitch on OrthoMechanica’s technology

3.2.  Semi-finalist at Orthopedic Research Society Business Innovation 

 


Last Modified: 07/15/2024
Modified by: Ravi Balasubramanian
